text: 1. Brahman (in the shape of prâ n a, breath) entered into that man by the tips of his feet, and because Brahman entered (prâpadyata) into that man by the tips of his feet, therefore people call them the tips of the feet (prapada), but hoofs and claws in other animals.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Then Brahman crept up higher, and therefore they were (called) 1 the thighs (ûrû).

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. Then he said: 'Grasp wide,' and that was (called) the belly (udara).

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. Then he said: 'Make room for me,' and that was (called) the chest (uras).

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. The S ârkarâkshyas meditate on the belly as Brahman, the Âru n is on the heart 2 . Both (these places) are Brahman indeed 3 .

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. But Brahman crept upwards and came to the head, and because he came to the head, therefore the head is called head 4 .

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. Then these delights alighted in the head, sight, hearing, mind, speech, breath.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. Delights alight on him who thus knows, why the head is called head.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. These (five delights or senses) strove together, saying: 'I am the uktha (hymn), I am the uktha 5 .' 'Well,' they said, 'let us all go out from

text: this body; then on whose departure this body shall fall, he shall be the uktha among us 1 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. Speech went out, yet the body without speaking remained, eating and drinking.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Sight went out, yet the body without seeing remained, eating and drinking.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Hearing went out, yet the body without hearing remained, eating and drinking.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Mind went out, yet the body, as if blinking, remained, eating and drinking.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Breath went out, then when breath was gone out, the body fell.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. It was decayed, and because people said, it decayed, therefore it was (called) body ( s arîra). That is the reason of its name.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 12. If a man knows this, then the evil enemy who hates him decays, or the evil enemy who hates him is defeated.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 13. They strove again, saying: 'I am the uktha, I am the uktha.' 'Well,' they said, 'let us enter that body again; then on whose entrance this body shall rise again, he shall be the uktha among us.'

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 14. Speech entered, but the body lay still. Sight entered, but the body lay still. Hearing entered, but the body lay still. Mind entered, but the body lay still. Breath entered, and when breath had entered, the body rose, and it became the uktha.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 15. Therefore breath alone is the uktha.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 16. Let people know that breath is the uktha indeed.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 17. The Devas (the other senses) said to breath: 'Thou art the uktha, thou art all this, we are thine, thou art ours.'

text: 18. This has also been said by a Ri shi (Rv. VIII, 92, 32): 'Thou art ours, we are thine.'
